user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 is: A project shall not contain dead code.
Any operation that is executed but whose removal would not affect program behaviour constitutes dead code. Notes:
1. The behaviour of an embedded sytem is often determined not just by the nature of its actions, but also by the time at which they occur.
2. unreachable code is not dead code, as it cannot be executed.
3.Initialization is not the same as an assignment operation and is therfore not a candidate for dead code.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtList_Add:
```c
void UtList_Add(UtListHead_t *ListHead, void *Data, uint32 DataSize, uint32 Tag)
{
    UtListNode_t *TagHead;
    UtListNode_t *NewNode;

    TagHead = UtList_GetHead(ListHead, Tag);
    if (TagHead != NULL)
    {
        NewNode      = UtList_NewNode(Data, DataSize);
        NewNode->Tag = Tag;
        UtList_Insert_Before(TagHead, NewNode);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UtList_Add:
UtListNode_t *UtList_GetHead(UtListHead_t *ListHead, uint32 Tag)
{
    if (Tag >= ListHead->NumberOfTags)
    {
        return NULL;
    }
    return &ListHead->Tags[Tag];
}
...
UtListNode_t *UtList_NewNode(void *Data, uint32 DataSize)
{
    union NodeAllocator
    {
        UtListNode_t Node;
        double       AlignDbl;
        void *       AlignPtr;
        long         AlignLong;
    } * AllocNode;

    AllocNode = malloc(sizeof(union NodeAllocator) + DataSize);
    memset(AllocNode, 0, sizeof(union NodeAllocator));
    AllocNode->Node.Data     = &AllocNode[1];
    AllocNode->Node.DataSize = DataSize;
    memcpy(AllocNode->Node.Data, Data, DataSize);

    AllocNode->Node.Next = &AllocNode->Node;
    AllocNode->Node.Prev = &AllocNode->Node;

    return &AllocNode->Node;
}
...
void UtList_Insert_Before(UtListNode_t *ExistingNode, UtListNode_t *NewNode)
{
    NewNode->Next       = ExistingNode;
    NewNode->Prev       = ExistingNode->Prev;
    NewNode->Prev->Next = NewNode;
    NewNode->Next->Prev = NewNode;
}
...
typedef struct UtListNodeTag
{
    struct UtListNodeTag *Next;
    struct UtListNodeTag *Prev;
    void *                Data;
    uint32                DataSize;
    uint32                Tag;
} UtListNode_t
...
typedef struct
{
    UtListNode_t *Tags;
    uint32        NumberOfTags;
} UtListHead_t
...
void UtTest_Run(void)
{
    UtListNode_t *         UtListMain;
    UtListNode_t *         UtListNode;
    UtTestDataBaseEntry_t *UtTestDataBaseEntry;

    UT_BSP_Lock();

    /*
     * The overall test sequence goes SETUP->TEST->TEARDOWN
     *
     * Combine all registered test groups into a merged group for execution.
     *
     * This could also (theoretically) randomize the order of the "TEST" group
     * while assembling this list, if there was a portable source of entropy.
     */
    UtListMain = UtList_GetHead(UtAssert_Global.DataBasePtr, UTASSERT_GROUP_DEFAULT);
    UtList_Merge(UtListMain, UtList_GetHead(UtAssert_Global.DataBasePtr, UTASSERT_GROUP_SETUP));
    UtList_Merge(UtListMain, UtList_GetHead(UtAssert_Global.DataBasePtr, UTASSERT_GROUP_TEST));
    UtList_Merge(UtListMain, UtList_GetHead(UtAssert_Global.DataBasePtr, UTASSERT_GROUP_TEARDOWN));

    UT_BSP_Unlock();

    /*
     * Run through the merged list in order
     */
    for (UtListNode = UtList_GetNext(UtListMain); !UtList_IsEnd(UtListMain, UtListNode);
         UtListNode = UtList_GetNext(UtListNode))
    {
        UtTestDataBaseEntry = UtList_GetObject(UtListNode);

        if (UtTestDataBaseEntry != NULL)
        {
            UtAssert_BeginTest(UtTestDataBaseEntry->TestName);

            UtAssert_SetContext(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TSF);
            if (UtTestDataBaseEntry->Setup)
            {
                UtTestDataBaseEntry->Setup();
            }
            UtAssert_SetContext(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_FAILURE);
            if (UtTestDataBaseEntry->Test)
            {
                UtTestDataBaseEntry->Test();
                UtAssert_Global.ExecutedCount++;
            }
            UtAssert_SetContext(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TTF);
            if (UtTestDataBaseEntry->Teardown)
            {
                UtTestDataBaseEntry->Teardown();
            }

            UtAssert_EndTest();
        }
    }

    UT_BSP_Lock();
    UtList_Destroy(UtAssert_Global.DataBasePtr);
    UT_BSP_Unlock();

    UT_BSP_EndTest(UtAssert_GetCounters());
}
...
void UtTest_AddCommon(void (*Test)(void), void (*Setup)(void), void (*Teardown)(void), const char *TestName,
                      uint32 EntryType)
{
    UtTestDataBaseEntry_t UtTestDataBaseEntry;

    memset(&UtTestDataBaseEntry, 0, sizeof(UtTestDataBaseEntry));
    UtTestDataBaseEntry.Test     = Test;
    UtTestDataBaseEntry.Setup    = Setup;
    UtTestDataBaseEntry.Teardown = Teardown;
    if (TestName != NULL)
    {
        strncpy(UtTestDataBaseEntry.TestName, TestName, sizeof(UtTestDataBaseEntry.TestName) - 1);
    }

    UT_BSP_Lock();
    UtList_Add(UtAssert_Global.DataBasePtr, &UtTestDataBaseEntry, sizeof(UtTestDataBaseEntry_t), EntryType);
    UT_BSP_Unlock();
}
...
void UT_BSP_Lock(void)
{
    OS_BSP_Lock_Impl();
}
...
void UT_BSP_Unlock(void)
{
    OS_BSP_Unlock_Impl();
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The listed fragments are flagged because they appear in places where their removal might not change observable behaviour (and therefore could be dead): the memset only zeros the union header but many of those fields are immediately overwritten; the initial self-linking of Next/Prev may be overwritten by the immediate insertion routine; NewNode->Tag is set but no use of the node Tag appears in the provided code; the UT_BSP_* wrapper functions are trivial pass-throughs and could be no-ops depending on the underlying implementation. All other fragments were examined and are not reported because they clearly affect program behaviour: - UtList_Insert_Before performs list pointer updates that are necessary to maintain list invariants. - UtList_GetHead performs bounds checking and returns the appropriate tag head; its conditional return is meaningful. - UtList_NewNode's AllocNode->Node.Data/Node.DataSize assignments and memcpy are essential to store the payload. - The UtTest_Run loop, the conditional calls to Setup/Test/Teardown, and the calls to UtList_Merge/UtList_Destroy/UtList_GetNext/UtList_IsEnd/etc are control-flow and data-flow operations that change program behaviour and thus are not dead. If desired, the flagged fragments should be investigated to determine whether they are redundant in this project configuration (true dead code) or present for defensive/portability reasons.
